_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



Accidental Release Prevention and Response Policies:

The Lost Creek Compressor Station prevents accidental releases by training plant personnel in the proper and safe operation and maintenance of the facility and by designing and constructing facilities with appropriate safety features included.  However, should a release occur, plant personnel will respond to control and contain the release.



Description of Facility and Regulated Substances Handled:

The Lost Creek Compressor Station is located approximately 0.5 miles north of Wamsutter, WY on East Carlton Road.  The plant is designed to process 275 MMSCFD of natural gas.  The natural gas is dehydrated and hydrocarbon liquids are removed, stored in atmospheric tanks and sold as condensate.  The plant process is idled when liquid hydrocarbon content in the feed gas is low enough that processing is not necessary but is always maintained and ready for immediate resumption of operation.  Design liquid production is approximately 120 BPD, but actual production rates have seldom been that high.  The plant has gas compression, dehydration, and utilizes a propane refrigeration process for hydrocarbon liquid recovery.  The plant contains propane (which is used as the refrigerant), mixed hydrocarbon liquids in the process, and natural gas which are all regulated flammables.  No threshold quantity of a regulated toxic is present at the plant site.



Offsite Consequence Analysis Results:

The Worst-Case Scenario (WCS) associated with a release of flammable substances at the Lost Creek Compressor Station is a vapor cloud explosion (VCE) from a catastrophic tank failure involving the full inventory of the largest storage tank containing propane. Physical limitations of the tank limit the storage inventory to 17,000 lbs. Therefore, the reduced inventory is assumed to release and ignite, resulting in a vapor cloud explosion (VCE). The maximum distance to the 1-psi endpoint for this WCS is 0.2 miles per RMP

Plan has been coordinated with the Sweetwater County LEPC.  The Emergency Response Plan has been posted at the plant and all employees have been trained in the actions to be taken in the event of an emergency.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

No changes to the safety program or station facilities are currently planned.
